title: An i for an ï and a ? for a tooth!
content:
Greetings for All Developing Typophiles  
Arabs unnecessarily do place Zamma before every Waw, Fatha before every Alif and Kasra before every Ya. And they use both tooth-like hamza + mark on or below Alif Though the mark alone indicates Hamza.  
I have been battling the web so that Arab make the change, but the only answer I get is:  
Our Fathers were on a course, and we are have to follow their footsteps?

Now, it is the turn to the latin-oriented.  
Triggered by the still-hot topic [Do ligatures improve readability?](http://web.archive.org/web/20071016222945/http:/typophile.com/node/28777) that I have been monitoring from the very beginning, I would like to ask:  
Why is there a dot on i and j? Why not dotless and why not using one dot for ï..?  
At least the “fi” problem (if any) is half-solved?! Do dots improve readability? Any other reason?  
Thinking Aloud, Allowed?!

 [‹ COOL typography websites](http://web.archive.org/web/20071016222945/http:/typophile.com/node/531 "Go to previous forum topic") [Best Font Sample Book creator ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20071016222945/http:/typophile.com/node/17721 "Go to next forum topic")

I think they initially had [tittles](http://web.archive.org/web/20071016222945/http:/typophile.com/wiki/tittles) to differentiate majuscule from minuscule, the umlaut or diaeresis performs a task in many languages (Albanian, Basque, Catalan, Dutch, Estonian, Finnish, French, German, Hungarian, Icelandic, Inari Sámi, Italian, Malagasy, Portuguese, Skolt Sámi, Slovak, Spanish, Swedish, Turkish), not just to the i, which in Turkish, Azerbaijani, Crimean Tatar and Tatar co-exists with the dotless ı.

Aziz, you’re thinking of nothing less than alphabet reform, something I’ve been pursuing (for Latin) since 1998, and I can assure you: you will encouter hordes of loud, outraged pseudo-intellectuals! Just try to do your own thing, and try to discover and nurture people who can actually think clearly. Without a king, and muzzled by democracy, there can be no quick, large-scale improvements.

hhp

As far as alphabet reform (at least for English), there have been many attempts, including [Deseret](http://web.archive.org/web/20071016222945/http:/www.utlm.org/onlineresources/deseretalphabet.htm) and [Unifon](http://web.archive.org/web/20071016222945/http:/www.unifon.org/), neither of which have a very broad following, but they make interesting studies.

Turkish Latin is itself a reformed alphabet, wherein the entire language was transferred from one writing system to another by decree, But, as evidenced by the complex system of accents the Latin alphabet isn’t particularly well suited to Turkish on its own.

It’s not particularly well suited to English either! :-)

BTW, almost all reforms have involved spelling. To me that’s REALLY hopeless. The other kind (what I work on) is purely graphic reform, which is a very different animal, not least in that it doesn’t hinge on any central authority.

hhp

The story on the i and j, IIRC, is that as black letter, especially textura evolved, it became hard to distinguish an i from the stems of the n, m, etc. And to distinguish it, they put a diagonal line above it. This evolved into the dot. The j was originally just a swashed i at the beginning of words. It was adopted in languages other than Latin, such as English, for a different sound than the i, and so became a separate letter.

The “j” was also used as a terminal “stopper” against forging lc Roman numerals.  
Don’t ask me to elaborate, that’s all I know. (Thamus, again. :-)

hhp
